title: Alf Steward
text:
Alfred Steward (born 18 September 1896 in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>, <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>) was an English <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He also played cricket for <a href="Lancashire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Lancashire</a>'s second eleven, though he did not appear in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a>.
Steward, a <a href="Goalkeeper%20%28association%20football%29">goalkeeper</a>, played football in the army between 1915 and 1918, before joining <a href="Stalybridge%20Celtic%20F.C.">Stalybridge Celtic</a>. In 1919 he joined <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> as an amateur, as cover for United first choice keeper <a href="Jack%20Mew">Jack Mew</a>. While an amateur he also played for <a href="Heaton%20Park%20F.C.">Heaton Park</a> before turning professional with United in January 1920. His United debut came in October that year, keeping a clean sheet in a 1–0 win at home to <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a>. He finally became a regular in the United side in the 1923–24 season, and was an ever-present the following season as United won promotion, as runners-up, to the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a>. Between April 1924 and September 1927 Steward missed only 7 league games out of a possible 139 for United, before losing his place to <a href="Lance%20Robinson">Lance Robinson</a>. He regained his first team place in April 1928 and went on to play a further 149 games before leaving Old Trafford in June 1932, joining <a href="Manchester%20North%20End%20F.C.">Manchester North End</a> as player-manager.
He led North End to the final of the Cheshire County League Cup against <a href="Altrincham%20F.C.">Altrincham</a> at the end of the 1932–33 season, a final in which he managed to play for both sides. The final finished in a 3–3 draw, but the replay was held over until the following season, by which time Steward had joined <a href="Altrincham%20F.C.">Altrincham</a> as player-manager. Altrincham won the replay 4–1, and later that season made the 1st Round of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> for the first time, losing to <a href="Gainsborough%20Trinity%20F.C.">Gainsborough Trinity</a>. They also won the Cheshire Senior Cup.
He finally retired as a player during the 1937–38 season, making just two appearances that season. In May 1938 he took over as secretary-manager at <a href="Third%20Division%20%28South%29">Division Three (South)</a> side <a href="Torquay%20United%20F.C.">Torquay United</a>. Torquay finished 19th in his only full season with the club, <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> intervening. He remained at Torquay until the club closed for the war in May 1940.
